text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This IRM provides guidelines for using email in the most effective and productive manner. It includes guidance on formatting messages in a way that will be easily accessible for all employees, including those using the Enterprise Remote Access System (ERAP). It also includes information on security guidelines, creation and use of distribution lists, and contacts for assistance with email issues.
All IRS employees
Table of Contents
for Using Email

) Email is now commonly used in business as an official form of often replacing memorandums, meetings or phone conversations. This ogy option is often the most efficient way to handle business and responsibilities. But its beneﬁts can lead to burdens if we do not use powerful tool judiciously. This section deﬁnes the standards for email use in Internal Revenue Service communications. (

) Email messages are official documents and should reﬂect this perspective. Email communications can be offered as evidence in court and can be binding. Before sending an email, you must consider how it reﬂects on the Service’s image and take into account privacy, records management, and security factors. (

) The privacy of email cannot be assured and is easily compromised. can be forwarded to unintended recipients (sometimes outside the agency even outside the government). The public we serve, or the Congress, who have occasion to see an email message, do not differentiate between employees as individuals and our agency. We are the IRS. (
) More information on the Service’s email security policy is available at curity’s policy. Refer to the Electronic Mail (Email) Security section and the Privately Owned Email Accounts section of IRM
) No officer of employee of the IRS may use a personal email account to conduct any official business of the government. For details, see the interim guidance in PGLD-

) Secure Messaging enrollment is an automated process for all LAN with an Exchange mailbox in IRS. You can ﬁnd the instructions for the Outlook client to use the certiﬁcates at the Secure Enterprise Systems (SEMS) web site: http://documentation.sems.enterprise.irs.gov/. (
) Alternatively, you may encrypt ﬁles to be e-mailed as attachments using latest software provided by IT. Instructions are provided at irs.gov/. (

) Individuals seeking to commit fraud or intending harm to the IRS or its employees often engage in a type of“social engineering,” called “phishing” Emails / wherein they use an alias and a seemingly innocuous cover story in order /“Social gain the victim’s conﬁdence and gather sensitive information. Such may use email, and try to trick you into revealing your password, or information. If you receive a suspicious, bogus, or phishing email: • Do not open any attachments • Do not reply • “Forward” the email to the electronic mailbox, (phishing@irs.gov) • Delete the email after forwarding For more information, see IRM
- Accounts Management and ance Services Operations. (

) All federal employees and federal contractors are required by law to records containing adequate and proper documentation of the Possible functions, policies, decisions, procedures, and essential transactions of the agency. Records must be properly stored and preserved, available for and subject to appropriate approved disposition schedules. (

) The Federal Records Act applies to email records just as it does to records you create using other media. Emails are records when they are: • Created or received in the transaction of agency business • Appropriate for preservation as evidence of the government’s and activities, or • Valuable because of the information they contain (
) If you create or receive email messages during the course of your daily you are responsible for ensuring that you manage them properly. The Archives and Records Administration, in OMB M-
, notes that by December

, federal agencies must manage all email records (both permanent and temporary) in an accessible electronic format. IRS offices move or copy their record emails to a separate electronic recordkeeping system unless their system has the features speciﬁed in IRM IRM that support records management and litigation requirements, including the Internal Revenue Manual Cat. All federal employees and federal contractors are required by law to records containing adequate and proper documentation of the organization, functions, policies, decisions, procedures, and essential transactions of the agency. Records must be properly stored and preserved, available for and subject to appropriate approved disposition schedules. The Federal Records Act applies to email records just as it does to records you create using other media. Emails are records when they are: • Created or received in the transaction of agency business • Appropriate for preservation as evidence of the government’s function and activities, or • Valuable because of the information they contain If you create or receive email messages during the course of your daily you are responsible for ensuring that you manage them properly. capability to identify, retrieve and retain the records for as long as they are needed. Some offices may need to print and ﬁle email records (along with related transmission and receipt data) if those offices still maintain paper re- cordkeeping systems (i.e. case ﬁles). (

) An email determined to be a federal record may eventually be considered as having permanent, historical value by the National Archives. Therefore, that all your communications are professional in tone. (

) The public is aware of the role emails play in agency internal operations and emails are included in a growing number of Freedom of Information Act requests. Emails that are responsive to a FOIA request must be released unless the information contained in the email falls into one of nine very categories of exemptions. (See IRM
for more on FOIA processing). There is no category of exemption to protect the author or the Service from embarrassment. (
) Emails provided in response to a FOIA must include the addressee, date time. The address list, date and time are considered part of the record for FOIA and record management purposes. (
) Do not delete a message or attachment that is the subject of a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), or discovery request or that is needed litigation. (

) Certain electronic records (like emails) may need to be identiﬁed and preserved when litigation is anticipated. In this case, you will be notiﬁed by your manager or Chief Counsel that relevant information must be preserved part of the legal process. See IRM IRM
Preserving Electronically Stored Information in Litigation Cases, and Chief Counsel Directives Manual CCDM
) IRM IRM

, Information Technology (IT) Security, Internal Revenue Service Policy On Limited Personal Use Of Government Information ogy Resources, deﬁnes the minimum standard for acceptable personal use Government IT resources by IRS employees. The ﬁrst exhibit, includes a summary of prohibited activities that includes creating, copying, transmitting, retransmitting chain letters or other unauthorized mass mailings regardless their subject matter. (
) The Spam Protection section of IRM
, states “Email spamming, or forwarding chain letters, other junk email, or inappropriate messages shall be prohibited.” In addition, the Electronic Mail (Email) Security section of
states “Any use of IRS IT resources, including email, shall be made the understanding that such use may not be secure, is not private, is not anonymous and may be subject to disclosure under FOIA.” (

) If you receive an inappropriate email, please notify your immediate or your local Data Security Area. Do not forward it to your co-workers, or family, etc. You should delete the inappropriate email after notifying the proper authorities.
Do not delete a message or attachment that is the subject of a congressional, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), or discovery request or that is needed for
1.10 Office of the Commissioner Internal Revenue
Office of the Commissioner Internal (

) Most IRS employees have access to email, but not everyone has the same email environment. Many employees work offsite and their email messages Format must go through the Enterprise Remote Access System (ERAP). A result is that these users often experience slower access and transmission. Email messages that IRS office workers download in fractions of seconds can often take longer for a ﬁeld user. Additionally, graphics and stationery can’t be read by adaptive equipment and can freeze the user’s system. (
) Unnecessary messages or excess volume of data within a message require time for the recipient to review and digest. Keep the reader’s situation and need in mind at all times. (

) To avoid slowing down transmission of information: • Use Arial or another simple font on a plain background. Slow Down the • Do not use animation, backgrounds, wallpapers, borders, graphics photographs or any other graphic element as part of your stationery message format or signature. Exceptions will only be allowed for IRS Commissioner initiatives. • Refrain from sending large attachments to work groups or audiences. Remember every email message and any attachments, embedded graphics and photographs require a copy for each Exchange server store where each recipient’s mailbox resides. Instead store the document on an IRS public web archive or Shar
oint repository and insert a hyperlink into the message. Ensure the permissions allow access by all recipients prior to sending the message. (

) A meaningful subject line helps recipients prioritize their email. Categorize all email by type. Include only related information in a message. If there is Messages another topic you wish to address, send it in a separate message. This it easier for the recipient to manage and respond to messages on different topics. (
) Use the follow-up ﬂag feature to identify items with required follow-up dates. (

) Most email will be normal priority. Designate an email as high priority only if the receiver will need to act on the message immediately. If your message is Priority truly urgent, consider trying to reach the recipient by phone or in person. • “!” – High. Example – Computers will be down this weekend so will not be scheduled and credit hours will not be approved. Example We need volunteers for a task force in Washington that will convene two weeks. Nominations are due this Friday. • “blank” – Normal (the default) • “down arrow”– Low. Example – The territory office of (another division) in another city has moved; its new address is… (

) Most email is of normal sensitivity. Messages designated as “private” or dential” should not be forwarded – but the system allows for this. Marking a Sensitivity message with one of these settings is advisory only. Recipients can take any actions on the message that they want to, such as forwarding the message others. Marking a message with one of these settings is advisory only. Recipients can take any actions on the message that they want to, such as forwarding the message to others.

Most email is of normal sensitivity. Messages designated as “private” or “conﬁ

dential” should not be forwarded – but the system allows for this. Marking a message with one of these settings is advisory only. Recipients can take any actions on the message that they want to, such as forwarding the message to others.

Private – Example: Communications with Labor Relations about an issue involving a particular employee. Conﬁdential – Example: A proposal you are sharing with someone for their input, but which has not been shared with those who will approve or implement the procedures. Normal (default)
improve the effectiveness of email, follow these rules of etiquette and sense guidelines: Consider whether email is the best method for your communication. Sometimes, two

way dialogue by phone, Office Communicator or in person may be more effective. At other times, email may be best if you need written documentation. Choose your recipients carefully. When selecting from the global address list, watch for duplicate names. If you frequently send messages to the same individuals, put them in your Personal Address Book. If two or individuals have the same names, check the employees’ properties in Global Address List to ensure your intended recipient is the right person the right location. Do not use a distribution list (as a convenience to you) unless your message is appropriate for everyone on that list. Use the subject line to categorize messages. Do not include any tial or sensitive information in the subject line. Forward messages only when necessary. Do not forward to people who have already received the message. Example: Do not resend Commis
sioner All

Employee messages. Be concise. Review your messages for accuracy in content, spelling, and Hint: Set auto spell check to check all messages before sending and review any changes made . If you say that a ﬁle is attached, attach it. Hint: attach the ﬁle before you compose the message. Insert hypertext links to large documents stored on IRS document tories. Maintain your Inbox. Respond promptly to messages. Routinely purge your mailbox of purely personal messages and work
related non
record emails. Non

record messages include to all employees (i.e., IRS Headlines electronic newsletter), and information/reference email and word processing ﬁles received “for your information” or as a carbon copy (CC) in which you were not expected to and on which you did not take action. Use the “To” address line for the primary recipient. Use the carbon copy “cc” and blind carbon copy “bcc” features appropri

ately. Avoid copying people who do not need to see your message. In an internal office environment, it is rarely appropriate to use the “bcc” Use “Reply to all” only if all the original recipients need to know your response. Otherwise, reply only to the sender. Never use “Reply to all” when you receive an email as a member of a large geographic or servicewide distribution list. Internal Revenue Manual
(11-17-2016) Follow Guidelines of Email Common and Etiquette
1.10 Office of the Commissioner Internal Revenue

q. Use conversational grammar. r. Do not use all caps or all lower case. Use punctuation. s. Use the “out of office assistant” or “ auto forward” features when you will be out of the office for an extended time. t. If you receive any messages with a known or suspected virus, delete immediately and report the matter appropriately . u. Avoid background, stationery or graphics. v. Use a simple font and font size that is easily readable. For example,

point Arial is generally easy to read. w. To accommodate those with visual impairments, select font and back- ground colors that provide sufficient contrast and avoid unusual color combinations. For example, use the default font color (usually black or blue) rather than selecting red or green, use the default background color rather than selecting a background color and do not use the text ing feature. x. Help prevent unnecessary email by telling recipients when your message does not require a reply. y. Manage your email more effectively by using Outlook features such as voting buttons and invitation options. It will be easier for recipients to respond and easier to manage and track the results.
Large attachments can degrade overall system efficiency, so you should limit the transmission of large ﬁles as email attachments whenever possible.

(3) If you are responding with an attachment, use “Forward ” instead of “Reply” because attachments do not stay with replies. (4) If you want to save the email message but do not need the attachment, follow these instructions: • Open the message, • Right click the attachment icon, and • Select remove from the menu. • Close ﬁle. Select “yes” at the “Do you want to Save changes?” prompt. This will also save disk space.

these instructions: • Open the message, • Right click the attachment icon, and • Select remove from the menu. • Close ﬁle. Select “yes” at the “Do you want to Save changes?” This will also save disk space. (

) Ensure attachments are safe from viruses. Open attachments only if you the source and are expecting the attached ﬁle. Because of the impact the spreading of worms and viruses have on the IRS network, the Enterprise Messaging System is now conﬁgured to block all ﬁles with particular If a ﬁle is sent via email with certain extensions (such as .exe, .vbs and the message will be deleted without delivery. (

) A number of virus variants try to bypass the IRS virus scanning software by including their damaging payload within a .zip ﬁle. Be cautious with any message you receive containing an attachment with a .zip ﬁle extension, only unzip the ﬁle only if you trust the source. (

) When you receive an email message with an attachment, save both the and the attachment to a hard drive or network drive as soon as possible remove the message and attachment from your mailbox. You free up space your server by doing so. (

) Distribution groups/lists are a convenience when messages need to be a large deﬁned group. They allow users to send email messages to each vidual on the list without selecting individual names. However, you should them judiciously. (
) Personal distribution lists are created by an individual user. Use your Help feature, keyword: personal distribution list, for instructions on creating sharing personal lists.

Ensure attachments are safe from viruses. Open attachments only if you trust the source and are expecting the attached ﬁle. Because of the impact the spreading of worms and viruses have on the IRS network, the Enterprise Messaging System is now conﬁgured to block all ﬁles with particular extension. If a ﬁle is sent via email with certain extensions (such as .exe, .vbs and .lnk), the message will be deleted without delivery.
1.10.3.3.7 (11-17-2016) Malicious Attachments
Office of the Commissioner Internal Revenue

Location Considered local in scope, these lists contain speciﬁc members from a local site. For example, functional coordinators within a service center campus. Special Cross multiple organization boundaries and are needs often created for temporary groups, such as task forces. Large lists Contain more than

members and require speciﬁc set up and delivery restrictions. The AWSS all employee list (&AWSS Employees) is an example. Note: The use of large global lists should be conﬁned to those who have a business need to communicate with the list. Examples include messages sent by IT to alert users of systems related issues or distribution of other approved servicewide communications tools such as IRS headlines or Leaders’ Alert. Lists Membership for these lists is determined by specify- created ing certain criteria within a database (such as TAPS from a or TIMIS) and populating the list with names database meeting the criteria. Changes to membership cannot be made directly to the list, but must be made to information contained in the database. The SB/SE all-employee list (&SBSE All) is an example.

) Distribution group/list managers can ﬁnd information on modifying a list in SEMS Documentation Library online at http://documentation.sems.enterprise. irs.gov/. (

) The IRS has the capability to send email messages to all employees; this method of communication should be used sparingly. If you have a for message you believe should be communicated servicewide, contact your business unit’s communication office. (
) Generally, information requiring communication to all employees is via th

RS Headlines electronic newsletter. The C&L Internal (IC) branch distributes IRS Headlines every Monday using the all-employee global distribution list. Content for IRS Headlines should contain information relevant to a cross-section of IRS managers and employees. Examples of items found in IRS Headlines are those that include: • Deadlines • Action Items • Strategic priorities and • Employee accomplishments (

) If you think you have information appropriate for IRS Headlines, you should take the following steps: a. Originator discusses topic and schedule with the business unit’s cation office. (If none, contact IC directly cl/cldir/

aspx.) b. Business unit communicator discusses topic and schedule with the IC son for that business unit. c. IC determines whether the topic is appropriate for IRS Headlines. d. Originator and business unit communicator draft message and submit it IC. e. IC will provide editorial feedback on content, length, tone, and key messages. f. IC will schedule article for publication in the IRS Headlines electronic newsletter. g. IC will suggest ways to incorporate message into other internal cations products, when appropriate. (

) On rare occasions, special circumstances may require the issuance of an employee email separate from IRS Headlines … and more. Any message submitted for distribution as an all-employee email will be subject to a review process. The communications manager in your business unit is your initial point of contact when deciding whether to start the process of creating an all-employee email. (

1.10.3.5.2 (11-17-2016) Special All-Employee Emails
When submitting a message for distribution to all employees, you must provide the following information:
Office of the Commissioner Internal Revenue
Signiﬁcance to employees (Is there something they must know immedi

ately to do their jobs correctly, to comply with the law, to prevent a systems failure, etc.?) Reason for extreme time sensitivity (Why is this information so critical employees that it cannot wait for inclusion in the next edition of Headlines?) Necessity of email delivery instead of Headlines or other method (Why does this information have to be sent via a special email? Why IRWeb (intranet) or Headlines be more appropriate ?) Desired outcome (What immediate action do you want employees to take?) Business objective
The C&L Internal Communication Branch will determine the best method of communicating the message based on the information submitted.

The Secure Enterprise Messaging system (SEMS) establishes a standard size of 500 MB (500 megabytes) for individual mailboxes. The system mails you daily warning messages that the limit is being approached when your mailbox reaches a size of 475 MB. When it exceeds the 500 MB limit, you will receive the following warning each time you attempt to send a message:

It is not the practice of the SEMS staff to adjust any individual mailbox storage limits, but rather to provide guidance on reducing the size of the contents. The Outlook Help menu provides instructions for enabling and conﬁguring both Auto-archiving and Rules to manage mail and mailbox folders to maintain proper storage
Your email signature section should include only the identifying information that would otherwise be included in any official IRS communication (i.e. business card, memorandum, letter, etc.):
Refrain from including quotes or other personal messages as part of the signature section.
these steps to create an automatic signature in Outlook:

Please note: Consistent with IRM 10.8.26.3.4 , Conﬁguration Management, if you’re using a mobile computing device with an email auto-signature capability, conﬁgure it so that it does not disclose that the email origi- nated from a smartphone or mobile computing device (e.g., do not have it show “Sent From My Wireless Handheld”).
